article.title: Getting Started with Strapi: A Beginner's Guide
article.description: Learn how to set up your first Strapi project, create content types, and build a REST API in minutes.
article.content:
## Introduction

Strapi is the leading open-source headless CMS. It's built with JavaScript, fully customizable, and developer-first.

## Why Strapi?

Traditional CMS platforms couple the frontend and backend together. Strapi takes a different approach by providing a powerful API layer that lets you deliver content to any frontend framework or device.

### Key Benefits

- **Open Source**: Full control over your code and data
- **Customizable**: Extend and modify anything through plugins and custom code
- **RESTful & GraphQL**: Choose the API format that works best for your project
- **Self-hosted**: Deploy anywhere you want

## Setting Up Your First Project

Creating a new Strapi project is straightforward:

```bash
npx create-strapi-app my-blog --quickstart
```

This command scaffolds a complete Strapi application with a SQLite database, perfect for development.

## Creating Your First Content Type

Once the admin panel is running, navigate to the **Content-Type Builder** and create a new collection type. Define your fields, set permissions, and start creating content immediately.

## What's Next?

In the next article, we'll explore advanced features like custom controllers, middleware, and deploying Strapi to production.

article.title: 10 Productivity Tips for Remote Developers
article.description: Practical strategies to stay focused, organized, and productive while working from home as a software developer.
article.content:
## The Remote Work Challenge

Working from home offers incredible flexibility, but it also comes with unique challenges. Distractions, isolation, and blurred work-life boundaries can all take a toll on your productivity.

Here are ten battle-tested tips that have helped me thrive as a remote developer.

## 1. Establish a Morning Routine

Start each day the same way. Whether it's a cup of coffee, a short walk, or 15 minutes of reading, a consistent routine signals to your brain that it's time to work.

## 2. Dedicate a Workspace

Even if you don't have a home office, carve out a specific area for work. Your brain will associate that space with focus and productivity.

## 3. Time-Block Your Calendar

Group similar tasks together and protect deep work blocks from meetings and interruptions.

## 4. Take Real Breaks

Step away from the screen. Go outside. The Pomodoro technique (25 minutes of work, 5 minutes of rest) is a great starting point.

## 5. Communicate Proactively

Over-communicate rather than under-communicate. Share status updates, ask questions early, and be responsive during core hours.

## 6. Invest in Good Equipment

A quality monitor, keyboard, and chair make a measurable difference in your comfort and output.

## 7. Automate Repetitive Tasks

Use scripts, aliases, and CI/CD pipelines to eliminate manual toil.

## 8. Set Boundaries

Define clear start and end times for your workday. Close the laptop and walk away.

## 9. Stay Connected

Join virtual co-working sessions, participate in community Slack channels, and schedule regular one-on-ones with colleagues.

## 10. Reflect Weekly

Spend 15 minutes each Friday reviewing what went well, what didn't, and what you'll change next week.

## Conclusion

Remote work is a skill. Like any skill, it improves with deliberate practice and honest self-assessment.

article.title: Exploring the Hidden Beaches of Portugal's Algarve Coast
article.description: A guide to the lesser-known coves, sea caves, and pristine beaches along southern Portugal's stunning coastline.
article.content:
## Why the Algarve?

Portugal's Algarve region is famous for its dramatic limestone cliffs, golden sand beaches, and crystal-clear waters. While spots like Praia da Marinha draw crowds, there are dozens of quieter beaches waiting to be discovered.

## Praia da Mesquita

Tucked between towering cliffs near Carvoeiro, this small beach is accessible only by a steep trail or by kayak. The effort is rewarded with near-solitude and stunning rock formations.

## Praia do Submarino

Named after a submarine-shaped rock formation visible at low tide, this beach near Portimao is often overlooked by tourists heading to the more famous Praia da Rocha nearby.

## The Sea Caves of Benagil

While the main Benagil cave is well-known, the surrounding coastline hides numerous smaller caves accessible by paddleboard or kayak. Early morning trips (before 9 AM) offer the best light and fewest crowds.

## Getting Around

Renting a car is the best way to explore the Algarve's hidden beaches. Many are accessible only via unpaved roads or coastal paths that aren't served by public transport.

### What to Bring

- **Water and snacks**: Many hidden beaches have no facilities
- **Sun protection**: The Algarve sun is strong, even in shoulder season
- **Water shoes**: Rocky entries are common at secluded coves
- **A dry bag**: Essential if you're kayaking to beaches

## Best Time to Visit

May through June and September through October offer warm weather, smaller crowds, and lower prices. July and August are peak season with temperatures regularly exceeding 35C.

## Final Thoughts

The Algarve rewards curiosity. Wander off the main roads, talk to locals, and don't be afraid to take that unmarked trail down to the water. The best beach is always the one you discover yourself.

about.title: About Us
about.content:
## Our Story

We started this blog with a simple idea: share what we know, learn from our readers, and build a community around curiosity and craft.

Our writers come from diverse backgrounds - software engineering, travel journalism, photography, and more - but we all share a commitment to creating content that's genuinely useful and thoughtfully written.

blocks.body:
## Our Mission

We believe that great content should be accessible to everyone. Our articles are free, ad-light, and written with care. We focus on depth over clickbait and substance over hype.

## Our Team

Our writers are practitioners first and writers second. When Sarah writes about Strapi, she's drawing on years of real-world experience. When Marcus writes about the Algarve, he's been there with sand between his toes.
